ExampleDefinition.ToolTipDescription: Shows how to create stacked mountain chart
ExampleDefinition.Description:
Generates a Stacked Mountain chart in code-behind. The [url='https://www.scichart.com/documentation/win/current/webframe.html#The%20Stacked%20Mountains%20Type.html']StackedMountainRenderableSeries API[/url] can be used to render mountain/areas stacked one above another.
Mountains are rendered using the [url='http://www.scichart.com/documentation/win/current/SciChart.Charting~SciChart.Charting.Visuals.RenderableSeries.BaseRenderableSeries~Stroke.html']Stroke[/url] (outline) and [url='http://www.scichart.com/documentation/win/current/SciChart.Charting~SciChart.Charting.Visuals.RenderableSeries.BaseMountainRenderableSeries~Fill.html']Fill[/url] (fill).
[b][i]Tip![/i][/b]
Did you know we support 100% Stacked Mountain charts? See the [url='https://www.scichart.com/documentation/win/current/webframe.html#The%20Stacked%20Mountains%20Type.html']Introduction to Stacked Series in SciChart[/url] article for more information.
[b]Documentation Links[/b]
- [url='https://www.scichart.com/documentation/win/current/webframe.html#The%20Grouped%20Column%20Series%20Type.html']Introduction to Stacked Series in SciChart[/url] - [url='https://www.scichart.com/documentation/win/current/webframe.html#The%20Stacked%20Mountains%20Type.html']StackedMountainRenderableSeries Type[/url]
